Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Collaborative Research: Turbulent Flame Structure of Cavity Stabilized Reacting Shear Layers: Effects of Flow Compressibility, Heat Release, and Finite-rate Kinetics

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1511791(Chelliah)/1511520(Cutler)/1510222(Edwards)

High-speed and supersonic combustion is of vital importance to high-speed transport. The research team comprised of experimentalist and numerical modelers will try to understand, using a unique facility and state-of-art numerical models, how fuel burning at such high speed happens and how stable combustion can be achieved. A team of undergraduate and graduate students will be involved in the research and the data and results will be widely published.

To understand the flame stabilization mechanism requires the understanding flame structure resulting from the interaction between the chemical reaction, which releases heat, and the flow. Under high-speed conditions, the flow is turbulent. The proposal focuses on this interaction under supersonic conditions where compressibility also plays a role. The flow geometry chosen is high-speed reacting shear flow over cavity, which is commonly believed to be a good candidate for supersonic combustion and propulsion. The proposed facility (located at the lead PI's institution - UVa) is unique, which has been developed over the past decades and is well and appropriately leveraged for the proposed research. Fundamental data on flame structure and statistics on key species are to be obtained experimentally. Computational results using DNS (Direct Numerical Simulation) will supplement the experiments to provide additional information not accessible from experiments in developing submodels, which can be used in the future development of high-speed propulsion combustors. The experimental data are of archival value. Close collaboration proposed with researchers from government labs would likely amplify its usefulness.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is part of a multi-institutional collaborative effort whose goals are to understand the turbulent combustion regimes associated with cavity-stabilized flames propagating in premixed or stratified mixtures, and to evaluate the applicability of specific turbulence models in Large Eddy Simulations (LES) based on experimental and Direct Numerical Simulation (DNS) evidence. The experimental research uses a unique high enthalpy reacting flow facility at the University of Virginia (Harsha Chelliah, Chris Goyne), advanced diagnostics provided both by the University of Virginia and the George Washington University, while state of the art simulations are performed by North Carolina State University (Jack Edwards) and Sandia National Laboratory (Jackie Chen). This work contributes generally to the understanding of combustion in propulsion and energy generation systems, and more particularly to the design of air-breathing engines for high speed flight, enabling these systems to be more efficient and effective, with faster design cycles and less prototyping and testing.

Experimentation and simulation are based around a common set of experiments in which a premixed ethylene-fueled cavity-stabilized flame is held in a simulated dual-mode scramjet combustor. The combustion flow domain has been sized to permit DNS of the experiment and experimental inflow and boundary conditions have been well characterized, enabling accurate LES and DNS. We (George Washington University) have used dual-pump coherent anti-Stokes Raman spectroscopy (CARS) to make simultaneous time- and space-resolved measurements to build up a picture of the distributions of major chemical species concentrations and temperature in the combustor.  We have also applied planar laser-induced fluorescence (PLIF) imaging which has allowed visualization of the hydroxyl radical, a good marker of the flame and combustion products region.  Analysis of the OH-PLIF images has allowed identification of the position of the flame surface as it varies with time, which data can be analyzed for parameters such as flame surface density and curvature, compared to of other types of flames, and used to validate the LES and DNS. These databases of measurements of temperature, major species concentrations, and flame front properties (such as density and curvature) we have generated will also be useful to other computational modelling teams not currently participating in this multi-institutional collaborative effort.

Accurate, simultaneous time- and space-resolved measurement of temperature and chemical species in high speed flames can only be done in an engine with dual-pump CARS.  Physical probes cannot be used as they either burn up or change the flow they purport to measure.  No other optical methods have this capability.   However, dual-pump CARS has a problem in that if flames are sufficiently thin (as occurs in this environment) the CARS measurement volume (which is 0.5-1 mm long and 0.05 mm in diameter) can straddle the flame.  Spatial averaging in the CARS volume tends to bias the measurement to lower temperature parts of the measurement volume due to a non-linear variation of the CARS signal intensity with temperature.  New techniques have been developed to correct for this error. These techniques also enable the more accurate use of dual-pump CARS for the study of combustion in other propulsion and energy generation systems. Software and techniques have been developed for the measurement of flame front curvature and flame front density from OH-PLIF images that are useful in the study of combustion in other propulsion and energy generation systems.

Modified by: Andrew D Cutler

Images (1 of )
  • The figure shows the experimental model. Flow is from left to right. Electrically heated air at 1200 K enters the nozzle from the left, the flow is accelerated to M=2, ethylene fuel is injected and mixed, shock waves slow the air and mix the fuel, and a flame is stabilized on the model insert.
    C. Geipel
    Andrew D Cutler
    Experimental model
  • This figure shows a composite of instantaneous planar laser-induced fluorescence images obtained in the flow over the cavity. The bright regions indicate the presence of the chemical species OH, a marker of combustion products.
    C Geipel
    Copyrighted
    Andrew D Cutler
    Composite of PLIF images above the cavity
  • This figure shows the optical setup of the coherent anti-Stokes Raman spectroscopy system that measures distributions of temperature and major chemical species. The model scramjet combustor is the vertical duct at top center through which the laser beams pass.
    A. Cutler
    Copyrighted
    Andrew D Cutler
    CARS optical setup
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project is part of a multi-institutional collaborative effort whose goals are to understand the turbulent combustion regimes associated with cavity-stabilized flames propagating in premixed or stratified mixtures, and to evaluate the applicability of specific turbulence models in Large Eddy Simulations (LES) based on experimental and Direct Numerical Simulation (DNS) evidence. The experimental research uses a unique high enthalpy reacting flow facility at the University of Virginia (Harsha Chelliah, Chris Goyne), advanced diagnostics provided both by the University of Virginia and the George Washington University, while state of the art simulations are performed by North Carolina State University (Jack Edwards) and Sandia National Laboratory (Jackie Chen). This work contributes generally to the understanding of combustion in propulsion and energy generation systems, and more particularly to the design of air-breathing engines for high speed flight, enabling these systems to be more efficient and effective, with faster design cycles and less prototyping and testing. Experimentation and simulation are based around a common set of experiments in which a premixed ethylene-fueled cavity-stabilized flame is held in a simulated dual-mode scramjet combustor. The combustion flow domain has been sized to permit DNS of the experiment and experimental inflow and boundary conditions have been well characterized, enabling accurate LES and DNS. We (George Washington University) have used dual-pump coherent anti-Stokes Raman spectroscopy (CARS) to make simultaneous time- and space-resolved measurements to build up a picture of the distributions of major chemical species concentrations and temperature in the combustor. We have also applied planar laser-induced fluorescence (PLIF) imaging which has allowed visualization of the hydroxyl radical, a good marker of the flame and combustion products region. Analysis of the OH-PLIF images has allowed identification of the position of the flame surface as it varies with time, which data can be analyzed for parameters such as flame surface density and curvature, compared to of other types of flames, and used to validate the LES and DNS. These databases of measurements of temperature, major species concentrations, and flame front properties (such as density and curvature) we have generated will also be useful to other computational modelling teams not currently participating in this multi-institutional collaborative effort. Accurate, simultaneous time- and space-resolved measurement of temperature and chemical species in high speed flames can only be done in an engine with dual-pump CARS. Physical probes cannot be used as they either burn up or change the flow they purport to measure. No other optical methods have this capability. However, dual-pump CARS has a problem in that if flames are sufficiently thin (as occurs in this environment) the CARS measurement volume (which is 0.5-1 mm long and 0.05 mm in diameter) can straddle the flame. Spatial averaging in the CARS volume tends to bias the measurement to lower temperature parts of the measurement volume due to a non-linear variation of the CARS signal intensity with temperature. New techniques have been developed to correct for this error. These techniques also enable the more accurate use of dual-pump CARS for the study of combustion in other propulsion and energy generation systems. Software and techniques have been developed for the measurement of flame front curvature and flame front density from OH-PLIF images that are useful in the study of combustion in other propulsion and energy generation systems.
